+Vivian Gendernalik The human brain, emotion, and senses are not 
particularly reliable indicators of objective truth, which is why science 
has far higher standards than simple untestable, unrepeatable, unverifiable 
human observation for evidence. I absolutely believe that you think you had 
these experiences and that you may well have had these experiences, but it 
in no way supports the existence of any of these things. When I was a kid, 
I had three imaginary friends: a skeleton, a witch, and a ghost. And 
believe me when I tell you that I actually SAW these three with my own eyes 
and interacted with them in meaningful and interesting ways. I think we can 
both agree that this was simply imagination, and I have no reason to 
believe any differently of your experiences.

Also, I was a Christian for 22 years, and then a Pagan for around three 
years, and now finally an atheist / philosophical Taoist (12 years), and 
I've had "religious experiences" as all three, all unique and all just as 
interesting under all three umbrellas of identification. They are quite 
fascinating, but again, I don't think they're evidence of much other than 
the power of human imagination and certainly not indicators of any truths 
regarding objective reality. I can tell you that my experiences as a 
philosophical Taoist have been far more profound in their content and 
ability to adequately explain the nature of reality, and far more 
consistent with modern cosmology and physics than those I had as a 
Christian or Pagan, but I'd hardly expect you to suddenly grant them 
objective validity and consider becoming a philosophical Taoist. I can 
guarantee you that I am not alone in my experiences either: when I stumbled 
across the Tao Te Ching and read it, it was eerily like someone had ripped 
open my head, extricated my experiences and thoughts, and transcribed them 
far more neatly, eloquently, concisely, and with more wisdom than I would 
ever have been able to do.

A near death experience (NDE) is similar to a dream. Physicians and 
neuroscientists suspect they're hallucinations caused by the process of the 
dying brain shutting down. NDEs result when the brain is deprived of oxygen 
along with euphoria-causing endorphins and electrical discharges in the 
hippocampus. Side effects of anesthesia or medications can also contribute 
to NDEs. Events recalled from an NDE are no more real than events in a 
dream.﻿

+OnGodspath I certainly won't question your story as it seems very personal 
and certainly a profound experience, and I want to thank you for sharing it 
with me. I am happy that you all survived such a devastating accident. I 
don't share your belief in supernatural forces, but I fully admit that we 
can't really know for certain.

I am an atheist, but that doesn't mean that I don't think that the universe 
and life is vastly more complicated than we have even begun to understand, 
and I regularly enjoy things like meditation because of the profound 
experiences it induces in me.

I agree that children can have very vivid memories (and it irritates me to 
no end when people discount my childhood memories of, for example, knowing 
I was gay at the age of four as being nonsense). I do question the ability 
of a three year old to have and understand those experiences, but I am a 
skeptic, and the truth is that we're unlikely to know whether or not his 
experiences were genuinely valid.

What does concern me is that some people (often people not even related to 
the events that happened) immediately leap on experiences like these as 
confirmation of THEIR beliefs and faith, when these experiences are 
interesting and should be evaluated purely as they are instead of with such 
a level of bias and presupposition. A near-death experience is not 
necessarily evidence for or against any faith and it should not be treated 
as such.
